awd_titl_txt: Closing the STEM Labor Gap through a Path to Graduation for Low Income, Rural Students
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "Path to Graduation" program (PTG) at the University of Arkansas aims to close the STEM labor gap by recruiting previously overlooked populations and increasing the number of low-income students, especially those from rural regions. Degree programs aimed at producing a high-quality STEM workforce are a national priority that underpins progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy.  While the STEM-based economy has been an enormous economic boon in some regions, others are falling further behind economically due in part to their inability to meet STEM labor demands. Arkansas is an example of one such state that struggles to meet its STEM labor needs, ranks 49th in college attendance, and 45th per capita in Bachelor of Science degrees in scientific and engineering fields. Previous STEM student recruitment and retention efforts have largely ignored the unique challenges faced by low-income students from rural areas. These students often struggle with academic persistence in college due to insufficient funds, poor academic preparation by their small, financially struggling schools, and little social support given the lack of college-going culture in their communities. PTG will adapt proven student retention and graduation initiatives to better address the financial, academic, and social barriers to success so that these students can thrive and succeed in their STEM studies. Not only will the program increase both the size and the diversity of Arkansas' STEM labor pool, it has the potential to create best practices for recruiting and retaining low-income STEM students, especially those from rural areas. These practices can then be implemented in other remote, economically challenged regions of the country, developing pipelines of STEM talent, creating new regional STEM technology centers, improving these regions' economic well-being, and bringing much needed diversity to STEM fields.

Through academic, financial, and social initiatives, PTG will help 36 students thrive and excel in their STEM degree programs at the University of Arkansas. Students will be recruited largely from rural, impoverished regions of Arkansas where large populations of underrepresented minority and first-generation students are prevalent but opportunities for a STEM education are not. Two cohorts of 18 STEM students per year will receive annually renewable scholarships of up to $4,500, or $5,500 if they join the Honors College. These students will participate in PTG's evidence-based retention and graduation initiatives, including: an in-residence summer bridge program; a Living-Learning Community (shared housing); Academic Success Advising; faculty and peer mentoring; and on-campus or industry-based research opportunities. PTG will help identify and describe the barriers deterring low-income students, especially low-income students from rural backgrounds, from achieving a STEM degree. PTG will develop and implement retention programs for low-income, rural STEM students and will contribute significantly to the STEM education literature by developing and evaluating much needed initiatives for under-served, low-income, rural populations that frequently struggle with academic persistence.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Path to Graduation (PTG) project at the University of Arkansas aimed to increase the number of low-income, rural students who successfully complete STEM degrees and are prepared for careers in high-demand fields. Over the life of the project, 38 undergraduate students received S-STEM scholarships and participated in a multi-layered support program that combined financial assistance with academic, social, and professional development.

Intellectual Merit:

PTG generated new insights into how targeted support programs can improve academic outcomes and persistence for students from under-resourced and rural schools. The project team adapted evidence-based retention practices such as peer mentoring, faculty mentoring, summer bridge programming, and early academic planning for a population of students who often enter college academically underprepared or uncertain about belonging at a large research institution. These practices were refined over time using student feedback and outcome data, resulting in meaningful improvements in student academic performance and persistence. One of the academic goals of the program was to help students reach Honors College eligibility during their time at the university despite not qualifying at admission due to high school GPA and standardized test score requirements. Ultimately, 53% of all PTG scholars, and 77% of those who remained in the program, achieved a cumulative GPA of 3.50 or higher at some point during their studies, making them eligible for Honors as current students.

PTG also contributed to national knowledge through dissemination at conferences such as ASEE and NACADA, and by informing the design of a subsequent NSF-funded S-STEM program (INNOV, NSF Award No. 2030297) that is now serving additional students with an 89% retention rate among upper-level participants. Customized evaluation tools, including a graduate exit survey, produced valuable data on the experiences and needs of rural and low-income STEM students and continue to inform programming on campus and beyond.

Broader Impacts:

PTG expanded access to higher education by developing recruitment strategies focused on rural areas of Arkansas that have historically had low college-going rates. Fifty-eight percent of PTG scholars were from rural communities which was more than triple the rural representation in the STEM population at the university. Many came from towns with little awareness of or connection to research universities. Through school visits, presentations, and partnerships, the program raised awareness among students, families, and educators about the attainability of a STEM education.

The project promoted economic mobility by preparing scholars to succeed in high-demand fields such as engineering, chemistry, biology, physics, and mathematics. Students gained career readiness through professional mentoring, internships, leadership training, and structured support that improved self-confidence and long-term planning. As graduates, they are contributing to the technical workforce while also serving as role models for younger students in their communities. Their visibility is helping shift perceptions about who can succeed in college and in STEM careers.

Within the university, PTG influenced institutional practice by demonstrating the value of adjusted course sequencing, structured mentoring, and proactive advising. These practices have been adopted by other programs and are now part of broader student success strategies. Faculty and staff gained deeper insight into how to support students with different educational backgrounds, and many continue to use the lessons learned from PTG in their teaching and advising.

Overall Impact:

The Path to Graduation project contributed to both the academic literature and to real-world strategies for broadening participation in STEM. It demonstrated that with thoughtful, data-informed support, students from rural and economically limited backgrounds can thrive academically and professionally. By the end of the project, PTG had improved student outcomes, shaped campus practices, and helped expand the national conversation about access, persistence, and success in STEM education.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/23/2025
Modified by: Carol Gattis
